facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1585 of 1968 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1585 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated July 23, 1963 of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 64 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 23, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 64 of 1958.

facts.text: Assessee is a public limited company.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hegde, J. This is an assessees appeal. The assessee is a public limited companypany

facts.text: Appeal relates to assessment year 1949-1950 corresponding to accounting year ending December 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and the appeal relates to the assessment for the assessment year 1949-1950, companyresponding to the accounting year which is the calendar year ending on December 3 1, 1948.

facts.text: Assessee company incorporated in 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companypany was incorporated in 1942. At the beginning it owned a distillery at Unnao.

facts.text: Assessee owned a distillery at Unnao at the beginning.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companypany was incorporated in 1942. At the beginning it owned a distillery at Unnao.

facts.text: Assessee acquired a refinery in 1943.

anchor.surface_text: It acquired a refinery in 1943. With effect from June 1, 1945, the assessee companypany obtained

facts.text: From June 1, 1945, assessee obtained on lease the New Sawan Sugar and Gur Refining Co.

anchor.surface_text: With effect from June 1, 1945, the assessee companypany obtained on lease the New Sawan Sugar and Gur Refining Co.

facts.text: From January 29, 1946 to April 23, 1946, assessee purchased 41,300 shares of the said company for Rs. 12,17,006.

anchor.surface_text: During the period from January 29, 1946 to April 23, 1946, the assessee companypany purchased 41,300 shares of the said companypany for Rs. 12,17,006/-

facts.text: On April 30, 1947, entire block of shares sold to Produce Exchange Corporation Ltd. for Rs. 8,46,750.

anchor.surface_text: On April 30, 1947 the entire block of shares was sold to Produce Exchange Corporation Ltd. for Rs. 8,46,750/-

facts.text: Transaction resulted in loss of Rs. 3,70,356.

anchor.surface_text: . The transaction resulted in a loss of Rs. 3,70,356/This loss was treated by the assessee

facts.text: Loss treated by assessee as trading loss for assessment year 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: This loss was treated by the assessee as a trading loss for the assessment year 1948-49.

facts.text: After setting off loss against other income, loss of Rs. 2,27,085 carried forward under s. 24(2) to 1949-50 and later years.

anchor.surface_text: After setting off this loss against the other income of the assessee companypany, a loss of Rs. 2,27,085/was carried forward under s. 24 2  of the Income- tax Act,

facts.text: Assessee claimed to set off unabsorbed loss from share business against profits in sugar business for 1949-1950.

anchor.surface_text: to the year 1949-50 and later years. The assessee claimed to set off this unabsorbed loss pertaining to the share business against its profits in the sugar business

facts.text: Income-tax Officer did not permit set off.

anchor.surface_text: for the assessment year 1949-1950. The Income-tax Officer did number permit this set off.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed order of Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner companyfirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal agreed with Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: In a further appeal, the Appellate Tribunal agreed with the companyclusion reached by the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal stated case under s. 66(2) at instance of High Court on question of whether evidence for distinct businesses.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter at the in- stance of the High Court, the Appellate Tribunal stated a case under s. 66 2  of the Act on the following question of law Was there any evidence before the Tribunal

facts.text: High Court by judgment dated April 23, 1963 answered question in affirmative against assessee.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated April 23, 1963, the High Court answered the question in the affirmative and against the assessee.

facts.text: Appeal brought to Supreme Court after certificate under s. 66A(2).

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been brought against the decision of the High Court after obtaining a certificate under s. 66 A   2  of the Act.

facts.text: Appeal heard by Supreme Court on February 6, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal came up for hearing before this Court on February 6, 1969.

facts.text: Supreme Court found Tribunal's statement of case incomplete and directed supplementary statement.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case however it is number possible for us to satisfactorily dispose of this appeal because the statement of the case submitted by the Tribunal is incomplete

facts.text: Tribunal submitted supplementary statement of case.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal accordingly submitted a supplementary statement of case.

facts.text: Supreme Court reframed the question: Whether share dealing and sugar manufacturing constitute same business under s.24(2).

anchor.surface_text: It accordingly reframed the question as follows Whether the business of the companypany of dealing in shares and the business of manufacturing sugar

facts.text: Tribunal submitted second supplementary statement of case.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has number submitted the second supplementary statement of case called for by this Court.

facts.text: Tribunal found single trading and profit and loss account including sales of spirit, sugar, molasses, stock and shares.

anchor.surface_text: The facts found by it are as follows There is a single trading and profit and loss account. In the same account the sales of spirit, sugar and molasses as well as stock and shares

anchor.surface_text: appear 1. 3 I.T.R. 632. The share transactions as well as the business has, been dealt with by a companymon Organisation,

facts.text: Common fund utilised for business and purchase of shares.

anchor.surface_text: A companymon fund was utilised both for business purposes as well as for the purchase of shares.

anchor.surface_text: A part. of the over-draft of Rs. 6,80,046/- taken from the. bank on December 31, 1947 has been discharged from out of the income of the business

issues.text: Was there any evidence before the Tribunal on which it could hold that the business in dealing with shares was distinct and separate from the business of sugar manufacturing and distillery?

anchor.surface_text: Was there any evidence before the Tribunal on which it could hold that the business in dealing with shares was distinct and separate from the business of sugar manufacturing and distillery?

issues.text: Whether the business of the company of dealing in shares and the business of manufacturing sugar and other commodities constitute the same business within the meaning of s. 24(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, in force in the year of assessment?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the business of the companypany of dealing in shares and the business of manufacturing sugar and other companymodities companystitute the same business within the meaning of s. 24 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, in force in the year of assessment?

issues.text: In determining whether two lines of business constitute the same business within the meaning of s. 24(2) of the Income-tax Act, whether the income-tax authorities must consider the inter-connection, interlacing, inter-dependence and unity furnished by the existence of common management, common business organisation, common administration, common fund and a common place of business?

anchor.surface_text: within the meaning of s. 24 2  of the Income-tax Act, the income-tax authorities must companysider the inter-connection, interlacing, inter-depend- ence and unity furnished by the existence of companymon management, companymon business Organisation, companymon administration, companymon fund and a companymon place of business.

arguments.claim: Prithvi Insurance accepted Scales v. George Thompson requiring dovetailing and non-separability of businesses; share transactions easily separable, no dovetailing, no interdependence or unity

According to Mr. Mitra the transanctions relating to the shares companyld have been easily separated

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ransaction business does number dovetail itself into the other business of the assessee companypany. Further there is neither inter- dependence or uni

arguments.court_reasoning: Prithvi laid down objective tests of common management, business organisation, administration, fund and place of business; concepts not ambiguous

arguments.claim: Share dealing and manufacturing sugar constitute the same business within s. 24(2) as facts show common management, business organization, administration, fund and place of business

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by this Court in Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras v. Prithvi Ins. Co. Ltd. in determining whether two lines of business companystitute the same business within the meaning of s. 24 2  of the Income-tax Act, the income-tax authorities must companysider the inter-connection, interlacing, inter-depend- ence and unity furnished by the existence of companymon management, companymon business Organisation, companymon administration, companymon fund and a companymon place of business. ... From the facts found by the Tribunal, it is clear that the share, transaction as well as the other businesses of the companypany were dealt with by a companymon management

arguments.claim: Tribunal's original statement of case is incomplete, omitting material facts like evidence on why shares purchased or inter-relation with sugar manufacture

anchor.surface_text: In the present case however it is number possible for us to satisfactorily dispose of this appeal because the statement of the case submitted by the Tribunal is incomplete and has omitted to state material facts bearing upon the question referred.

holdings.text: In determining whether two lines of business constitute the same business within the meaning of s. 24(2) of the Income-tax Act, the income-tax authorities must consider the inter-connection, interlacing, inter-dependence and unity furnished by the existence of common management, common business organisation, common administration, common fund and a common place of business.

anchor.surface_text: within the meaning of s. 24 2  of the Income-tax Act, the income-tax authorities must companysider the inter-connection, interlacing, inter-depend- ence and unity furnished by the existence of companymon management, companymon business Organisation, companymon administration, companymon fund and a companymon place of business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly applying and pointing to the precedent in Prithvi Insurance Co. Ltd. as the governing test for determining if multiple businesses constitute the same business under s. 24(2).

holdings.text: From the facts found by the Tribunal, it is clear that the share transaction as well as the other businesses of the company were dealt with by a common management, common business organization, common administration, common fund and common place of business.

anchor.surface_text: From the facts found by the Tribunal, it is clear that the share, transaction as well as the other businesses of the companypany were dealt with by a companymon management, companymon business organization, companymon administration, companymon fund and companymon place of business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's supplementary findings of single trading account, common organisation, common fund utilised for both, common place of business satisfy the objective tests from Prithvi Insurance for interconnection, interlacing, interdependence and unity.

holdings.text: The concepts of inter-connection, interlacing, inter-dependence and unity are not free of ambiguity but this Court has laid down certain objective tests in Prithvi Insurance Co. Ltd., namely the existence of common management, common business organisation, common administration, common fund and common place of business.

anchor.surface_text: The concepts of inter-connection and inter-lacing, inter- dependence and unity are number free of ambiguity. But this Court has laid down certain objective tests for finding out  1  63 I.T.R. 632.  2  13 Tav. Cases 83 the existence of inter-connection, inter-lacing inter- dependence arid unity between two or more businesses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects Revenue's argument for subjective 'dovetailing' and non-separability test from Scales v. George Thompson; clarifies Prithvi provides unambiguous objective criteria, reiterated in Produce Exchange Corporation Ltd.

holdings.text: The statement of the case submitted by the Tribunal is incomplete and has omitted to state material facts bearing upon the question referred.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case however it is number possible for us to satisfactorily dispose of this appeal because the statement of the case submitted by the Tribunal is incomplete

holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessary details like reasons for share purchase and inter-relation with sugar business absent, preventing satisfactory disposal; directs supplementary statement under s.66(2).

holdings.text: The question referred by the Tribunal was defective and restricted the scope of the enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: This Court was also of the opinion that the question which the Tribunal was directed to and did refer was defective and restricted the scope of the enquiry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Original question on 'evidence for distinct businesses' too narrow; reframed to directly address if same business under s.24(2), directing further supplementary with Prithvi guidance.
